üõë This file is source code, not the primary documentation location! üõë

See https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/no-namespace for documentation.

TypeScript historically allowed a form of code organization called ‚Äúcustom modules‚Äù (module Example {}), later renamed to ‚Äúnamespaces‚Äù (namespace Example). Namespaces are an outdated way to organize TypeScript code. ES2015 module syntax is now preferred (import/export).

This rule does not report on the use of TypeScript module declarations to describe external APIs (declare module 'foo' {}).

Examples

Examples of code with the default options:

‚ùå Incorrect

module foo {}
namespace foo {}

declare module foo {}
declare namespace foo {}

‚úÖ Correct

declare module 'foo' {}

// anything inside a d.ts file

Options

allowDeclarations

Examples of code with the { "allowDeclarations": true } option:

‚ùå Incorrect

module foo {}
namespace foo {}

‚úÖ Correct

declare module 'foo' {}
declare module foo {}
declare namespace foo {}

declare global {
  namespace foo {}
}

declare module foo {
  namespace foo {}
}

Examples of code for the { "allowDeclarations": false } option:

‚ùå Incorrect

module foo {}
namespace foo {}
declare module foo {}
declare namespace foo {}

‚úÖ Correct

declare module 'foo' {}

allowDefinitionFiles

Examples of code for the { "allowDefinitionFiles": true } option:

‚ùå Incorrect

// if outside a d.ts file
module foo {}
namespace foo {}

// if outside a d.ts file and allowDeclarations = false
module foo {}
namespace foo {}
declare module foo {}
declare namespace foo {}

‚úÖ Correct

declare module 'foo' {}

// anything inside a d.ts file

When Not To Use It

If you are using the ES2015 module syntax, then you will not need this rule.
